instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP1V05_S5: What is PP1V05_S5? PP1V05_S5 is a 1.05v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. On 2008-2009 15” and 17” Macbook boards, this often gets stuck at 0.3v due to a bad C7771 capacitor. .
definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR> replaced. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.5v

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is cycling between 3.3v and 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
VCORE cycling too?
Did you try SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is cycling between 1.1v and 0v.



I cant even turn it off, when i press the power off button, it doesnt do anything, all i saw was the fan spin up and down every 3 seconds.

Any other way to do SMC bypass mode without the power button?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
You must press (and maintain) power button before connecting charger.

Is this symptom the same as before changing <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR>?

Any history fault available?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
i press and maintain power button, then connect charger, NO GREEN LIGHT, then release charger... same thing, fan spin up and down, the different is this time the fan spin higher and louder.

Nothing shown on the screen.

Symptom same as before changing <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR>. 

No history available, board looks very clean, untouched, not tampering sign

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
GPU voltages cycle too?
You can have CPU, or GPU issue.
Something changes if remove the RAMs?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_ALL_GPU_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is cycling...

remove RAMs make no difference

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
Work with board alone on the desk.
Check if all voltages from pages 71/72 try to appear.
Also test if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS are stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
If you means " Misc Power Supplies" and " Power FETs", then I have checked and they all cycling too, except of course <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> because <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> does not exist.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are stable. There is no <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> signal on this board.

When the board is in the machine, how come it doesnt wait for me to press the button before it try to power on? as long as the magsafe is plugged, the fan will start spinning up and down, with the front led going on and off at the same time...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
All iCore machines start directly, if no battery present.

"except of course <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> because <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> does not exist."
You didn't read the Apple note from schematic :confused:.
Do you get a pulse (at least) on <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL>???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message: I dont have any oscilloscope, but my voltmeter is showing  <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> is cycling between +0.005v and -0.004v :rolleyes:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
If you are able to detect pulsing all the other voltages, should not be a problem to detect <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL> too.
More than that, this voltage comes from <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, which you said is stable.
Post diode mode to ground (at <SIGNAL>1V05_S5</SIGNAL>).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
i still dont understand,  <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> should be "NO STUFF" and how it comes from <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>? I checked other <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board and <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> is also not presence..

diode mode to ground is 1 (open), other <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> also confirm the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message: Did you read Apple note from that page???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
I can only see:

" [B]1.05V S5 LDO[/B] Ibex Peak-M requires JTAG pull-ups to be powered at 1.05V in S5. Pull-ups (3) must be 51 ohms to support XDP (not required in production). 70mA is required to support pull-ups. Alternative is strong voltage dividers (200/100) to 3.3V S5, which burns 100mW in all S-states. "

Are we looking at the same page? Bottom right "PAGE 77 OF 132/SHEET  71 OF 101" ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
"Alternative is strong voltage dividers (200/100) to 3.3V S5"
So <CHIP>U7740</CHIP> is not required...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
ok... where is this voltage dividers then? where should I be measuring?

If i measure at the solder pad of the missing  <CHIP>U7740</CHIP>, I get nothing... diode mode to ground is just 1....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
I never found these resistors; also didn't search them.

You said to have another 2850 board.
Do you get 1V05 there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message: no there is no 1v05 there on another 2850, diode mode also read 1... perhaps these are only meant for the jtag and not required in production(as it said)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message: PCH has internal pull-ups for JTAG signal, in theory this circuit is only required to actually use JTAG when debugging. Some board models still have it populated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
On other boards I've checked, this voltage was always present.
Seems that is not needed now.

You can try disabling GPU.
Required information should be already posted on the forum.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
You have given me a zipfile before that contain images to bypass GPU but I checked the details it seems like it is actually just disconnecting gpu datalines around gmux and solder LVDS directly onto iGPU data lines, without actually disabling/power down the GPU chip. Maybe I have overlooked? 

On the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>, you told me I could diable GPU by removing <RESISTOR>R8904</RESISTOR>/11. But if i remember correctly, I cant do the same on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Is there a way to just power down the GPU on these 2850 board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> fan spin 3 seconds and stop, then loop
threads.message:
You should also remove corresponding resistor which powers up GPU controller from its power supply.
But is not sufficient to stop the GPU power.
